text: 12oz bottle pours out golden topped with a white head. Nose is grain light grassy notes some nutty notes. Taste is as the nose with a nice light grain and crisp end.

Very hazy amber and copper coloured body with a thin, single centimetre tall off-white head. Aroma of peaches, apricots, alcohol, wheat, grain and more fruits - very nice and fairly low key. Medium-bodied; Dense malty flavour with some fruits, nuts, earth and more pungency from the lager yeast. Medium-bodied; Assertive nutty and earthy flavours with a big peach and apricot flavour showing some bitterness and funk coupled with a bit of the grain. Aftertaste shows some pungent alcohol notes, some light fruit flavours and a lot of malt, which is relatively surprising, given the style. Overall, a good and very flavourful lager with a ton of fruit flavours and nice maltiness. Great to sample, and a good option should you want a full-bodied and full-flavoured lager in the summertime! I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from Whole Foods in Fair Lakes (Fairfax), Virginia on 18-October-2015 for US$1,99 sampled at home in Washington on 17-October-2016, a full 365 days later!

Bottle. It pours a clear golden color with a foamy white head. The aroma is mostly bready and kinda sweet smelling with light hints of honey and flowers. The flavor is full bodied and bready with more honey and flowers. Mostly pale malts, but on the sweet, under attenuated side. Ok. A little heavy for me.
Bottle from Chevy Chase Supermarket. Golden amber body with thin head. Nose is malty, spicy. Taste similar, wheat, malts and punch abv. Sweet and syrupy in the finish. Pretty good.
12oz bottle. Poured a golden color with a smaller sized off white head. Bread, some earth, sweetness and grains.

[Bottle (12oz)] Pours a clear deep gold with an average size frothy lasting off-white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is fruity, malty, very lightly hoppy and lightly vegetal. Flavour of caramel malt, grain. some hops, light vegetal notes and a decent and long bitter finish. Medium bodied. Pretty good.

Darker hue of golden. Fleeting white head. Uninviting nose of wet bread, grape candy, floral hops, cereal flakes, nuts, and paintlike yeast. Restrained carbonation. Grapelike notes abound on entry and are exacerbated by a sting of alcohol and a sweetness that teeters on medicinal. Limp, poorly defined malt shows faint nutty edges, but is devoid of melanoidins and shows more of a wet bread effect than anything. Hints of apple juice heighten the incessant sugars and flabby malt. Strong prickle of alcohol, throughout. Hops are softly floral, though fail to alleviate the sugary fatigue. Sweet and alcoholic finish contains notes of honeyed white bread and floral suggestions. A rather predictable heller bock that lacks the bright hops and melanoidiny punch I seek in the style. Would love to see more minerals, as well. Meh.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: I dont see this style around much, which is a shame, so thanks to Troegs. Is a maibock and a Helles bock and a Heller bock all the same? Pleasantly sweet on the palate and the nose. Some cookie dough, vanilla, allspice, and cream. Good.

A very nice Maibock that is dialed in quite nicely as an example of the style and one that is brewed in the US.

FYI, there is no corn in this all malt beer either to smell or to taste.
Bottle from Kroger. Pours deep golden with a small white head. Aroma of corn, bread, and grains. Taste is very similar. Bread crusts, corn, grass. Meh, just boring.

A golden pour into the glass with a medium head that leaves spotty window-wash lacing. Aromas of sweet corn, grains, and hops. Nice body on this. Medium-round mouthfeel with active carbonation. A nice combination of flavors... grains, corn, sweet bready notes, floral bitters... all finish with a nice curt ending. The palate is perfect for spring/summer nights, not too heavy, but substantial and complex nonetheless. A very good Helles, and one that stands out from the crowd in a very crowded genre.

Bottle. Pours a nice looking dark golden beer. Medium head. Clear. Aroma is fresh grains, floral hops, crisp bread. Light sweetness, light bitterness. Biscuit and grains with light caramel and hop notes. Crisp. Solid. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a reddish Amber with an off white head. Taste is surprisingly malty. Nicely balanced with a bit of earth and straw offsetting the malt. Finish is dry. 



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
355ml bottle. Golden pour. Very rich and malty, like barley oatmeal, delicate hops, prtty nice.
On tap. White-yellow/gold. Nice floral, grain/lt malt. Taste- flllows with a nice hop fiinish.

Nice looking pale gold with sturdy white head, Very bready aroma and up front, toasted malt follows and fairly aggressive hopping for the style, but adds nice offset to the malt, finishes fairly clean. Nice beer. Also, Im liking the new clean packaging from Troegs.

Poured from bottle. 
Aroma of bread and spice. 
Appearance is clear gold, a bit of head. 
Tasting bread, vanilla, coriander, pepper, floral/ pine hops, caramel and toffee. 
Quite drinkable - not too carbonated and full flavored. 
Overall, a tasty, enjoyable brew.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Clear medium copper pour. Smells of sweet fermenting bread dough, lager funkiness, and springtime flowers. Tastes sweet - oaty, creamy, caramel, toffee. Really nice full mouthfeel that has some spring to it - almost chewy.

It pours a light amber with a white head. It has earthly aromas with grass, floral homes and some toast. It has flavors of earthly and toast with the grass and floral elements providing complimentary flavors.

Where: Old Line Fine Wine Spirits & Bistro. 
How: Half pint pour.
Appearance: Crystal clear golden yellow with one finger white head, short retention light lacing. 
Aroma: Traditional lager scents of light caramel and corn.
Taste: Nice full flavor, deep malt character with the refreshing lager traits but a nice bit of hop profile full front and center and thats where the finish lingers. 
Palate: Body is rather full, nice and round.
Overall: If you dont know the style, try it. Its very complex and interesting.

DATE: April 8, 2016... OCCASION: a loooong week ends in beer-tasting Friday... GLASSWARE: Celebrator doppelbock pokal.. APPEARANCE: the helles is definitely apparent at first sight, with a copper golden body that sparse effervescence; a thin, creamy mustache ring around the glass; the body is clear... AROMA: pitched malt grains are toasted and oat and cereal... the hops are fruity and aromatic, almost like freshly mowed grass and flowers... PALATE: sharp, medium-bodied, slick and soft on the tongue...a body that bewitches with its near 7% ABV... TASTE: .though no taste is dominant, the sweetness of caramel and toffee takes the lead... the hops soften the experience, with the floral fragrance adding some balance... malted and toasty, the aftertaste lingers enough to invite the next drink... its drinkability is centered in its light, engaging flavor profile... OVERALL: Troegs has done right with this one, where a powerful bock has wedded a crisp, soft helles with beautifully drinkable results...
clear amber color; earthy malt aroma; well balanced; earthy, bready malt with a good deal of hop bitterness

APPEARANCE- light amber color with orange notes. Light head leaves no trace on the sample glass. 
NOSE- clearly malty, with mild sweetness. Clear that its a bock, but everything about it says subtle bock scents. 
FLAVOR- malt forward on the sip, slight hop bitterness near the end. Good flavored bock, and i coud spend all bock fest weekend drinking this one. NOTES- the deScription indicates floral hops, but there is very little of that.

I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass. It pours copper with a thin white head and lacing. The aroma is earthy and hoppy. The taste is earthy, hops, bitterness, and some subtle sweetness. Its a little thin. I thought this was average. It hid the higher alcohol content pretty well though.
Tap. Clear darker gold. Earthy leafy hop notes, sweet hay and sweet fruit my malts in the aroma. Flavor is sweet, like light caramel, some earth, light fruit akin to reddish pears. Medium slick body.

Bottle from Table and Vine. Clear gold with long lasting head and lace. Crackery grassy honey aroma with a touch of spice. Medium sweet crackery honey lightly toasted grainy sweetness with medium spicy grassy bitter very clean finish. Medium body nicely attenuated no stickiness. Not a favorite style but this is wicked fucking good.
Bottle. Clear bronze color. Faint smell of grass, floral, hops, pine and toasted malt. Taste notes of hop, pine, citrus, malt, bouquet and nut. A general earthiness. Thin body, quick duration.

On tap at Tasty. Pretty average for me. Was hoping for something more hoppy like the Helles Bock from the Wedge. This drinks too sweet and malty/bready for my liking. Overly floral. Having it next to pineapple sculpin from Ballast Point probably didnt help. Meh.

Attractive cloudy golden pour w/ a white head & decent lacing. The enticing aroma contains grains & subtle floral hops. The taste is slightly dry & surprisingly not all that interesting. The dry breadiness drowns out the hops. Wish it tasted as good as it looks & smells!
Sample @ PGH Beerfest. Some light bready aroma and taste with some light malts. Not very refreshing or flavorful. Did not really like this that much. It wasnt bad but just not that good.

Honey malt. Clean, fairly crisp yeast. Fresh hops sit on top, providing some citrus and spice, complementing but not overpowering a malty beer. Obviously on the sweet side due to the style, but nicely balanced. Good spring choice.

Pours a light copper with a thick white head. Crystal clear with lots of fine bubbles. Aroma is toasty malt with a little spicy hop note behind it. Taste is crisp and lightly malty. A little grainy, toastiness. Finishes dry with a spicy bitterness. Medium bodied with sparkling carbonation.

Overall an excellent lager, malt-forward with just enough hops to balance it.
Clear amber gold with a thin white head. Grainy and sweet on the nose. Medium bodied, sweet honey and grain. Light bitterness into the finish.
Sweet grain aroma. Nice alcohol warmth with a slight bready and bannana taste.

Can from Drum Hill 
Slightly hazy deep yellow color with a decent sized bubbly white head. Rich toasted pilsner maltiness with hints of floral hop to counter. Sweet bready flavor with rich hints of toast and light caramel, light spice hop flavor. Faint bitterness leans towards malt in spades. Touch of alcohol in the finish. Nice sipper, not sure if the age hurt or helped this, but I just noticed this was a spring seasonal.
Pissy yellow appearance with decent head. Aroma is super candy malt with a hint of funk. Taste is sweet, bready malt. Not bad.

[7402-20150724] Bottle. Straw grains aroma. Clear, pale orange body with a quick foamy white head. Mild fruity grains and star flavour with a light bitter base. Medium body. Average. (6/3/6/3/13) 3.1-
(w/ jercraigs, wilco, & friends)

2015-07-24. Lightly hazy dark yellow body with a small white head. 3+ Aroma of pale malt, cereal grains, light alcohol. Flavour has similar pale malt and grain character, moderate alcohol throughout. Average plus bodied palate, soft carbonation. Decent example of a style I am not personally overly fond of. Bottle from the brewery.
Sweet grain aroma. Golden body with an orange hue. Bitter grain taste. Sweet toasted grain is the best I can describe.

8/VI/15 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ home - BB: n/a, bottled II/11/15 (2015-762) < /i> Thanks to Dieter A. for sharing the bottle!
Clear deep blond beer, creamy irregular head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: very malty, wort, grains, hay. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: grains, sweet malts, little bitter, some citrus. Aftertaste: green banana, bit yeasty, malts, bitter.

pours a cloudy orange amber with light foam and light carbonation. Has a faintly sweet floral aroma to it. When you first drink it you can taste a little sweetness and the floral hops but immediately afterwards you get a strong bitter taste which must be the toasted grains in the beer. Has a bit of a dry after taste and kind of bitter but not too bad of a beer.
Amber gold little rim head; little aroma; Flava malty sweet but dry; feels medium to thick and silky little zingy fizz at end; finishes dry slight tangy malt bitter

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle. Bottled on 021115. Pours yellow and heady into my my glass mug. The aroma has a pleasant grainy note with a touch of bread and grassy hops. The body is light to medium. The taste is toasty at first with a clean hop finish and also kind of green like a big field.
12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured golden, clear with a small white head. Aroma is bready, some citrus fruits and some hops. Taste is a bit sweet, biscuit, hops, and malts. Dry finish. Very decent.
Taste is semi sweet with a crisp hint of ale n hops rounded out by a robust malty ceareal slightly recalling some floral goodies. Well done Troegs. Golgen hue and slightly spruced.
Orange and cantaloupe nose. Clear amber, thin head. Cantaloupe and orange peel. Medium body. Interesting hop bill for a heller bock, but I like it.

Appearance: deep clear gold, a finger of white head.  Aroma: 	grainy, with toasted white bread, honey, fresh cut grass, maybe some lemon pith.  Taste: as the aroma indicated.  Finish: fulsome, lingering sweetness and some grass. Notes: Not bad at all. Rather enjoyable. Bottle from Total Wine & More in Fairfax, Virginia (Pickett Center).

Clear , golden color. Decent white head. Grainy aroma with light herbal and citrus notes. Intense , malty taste, hint of caramel , pleasant hoppy bitterness. When I was drinking it , I realized how I missed German style beer. Very good.
Easy to drink with light grain profile. Pours golden. Crisp finish with hint of sweetness. Tap at world of beer in Ballston.

Pours a crystal clear deep gold color with a medium white head. The aroma is bready malt. Taste is sweet malts, light caramel, and biscuit, that is moderately sweet. Medium to light bodied with mild carbonation. Nice.

Aroma: bread, floral, 
Appearance: clear, golden, thick white head
Taste: light sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate: medium body, slick feel, lively carbonation, abrupt finish

Nice.
Drank from bottle. Lemon and biscuit nose. In the mouth, mute light Lennon, a bit of malt, mild hop finish. Easy drinking sitting/summer brew.

Meh...as far as the style goes its pretty good. I just dont care for heller bocks. Aroma was lager yeast and grains. Pour was a nice clear medium gold with a one finger white head. Taste was same as the aroma. Very grainy and sweet with fresh baked bread and light malt. Mild carbonation.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Slight haze to the yellow hue. Thin white head. Faint sweet nose. Sweet malt flavor with hint of hop bitterness seconds after the swallow. Medium body. Seems pretty straight to style.
Norfolk bottle for CC course. Just really wanted a fresh spring beer to enjoy in season and this delivered in all its malty, bready and lightly hoppy goodness. True to style.

Draft at craft ale house. Pours clear golden with a medium sized white head. The aroma has cracker, biscuit. The taste is crisp, clean, a tad sweet on the finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Light golden color out of the can with a foamy white head. Crisp cracker and lemon zest nose. Light crisp flavor with lots of cracker, subtle lemon cookie and a dry hoppy finish. Caramel sweetness with a bit of fruit. Tasty beer.
Pours gold with a thin white head. Aroma of bitter hops, grain and sweet malt. Taste is bitter yet slightly sweet and biscuity. Nice hoppy lager.
Pours a mostly translucent golden with a small bubbly white head. Aroma of soft pretzels, floral notes and lightly toasted rye bread. Flavor of toasted bread, grapes, crackers and floral notes.

Pours light golden.
Good Pilsner lager kind of beer. Mouthfeel is light. Tastes fruity yeast and very light hops. Good all time beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I freaking love Troegs. I grew up drinking this stuff as a little whippersnapper in Hershey, PA. Clear golden-copper color with a large white head and good retention. Biscuity and bready malt aromas with a hint of sweetness. The flavor is mildly sweet, a touch of honey, bread, and floral hops. Medium-light bodied and smooth. Pretty nice offering for the style.
12 oz bottle from Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. Smooth, crisp and lemony. Nice for a warm summer day.
Draft. Hazy deep golden color, medium white head. Aroma of nutty toast. Taste has white pepper, straw, hay. Decent.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2015 Bottle into pint glass, clear light amber color with white head. Aroma notes of bready malt and light floral hops. Taste adds some light caramel and faint fruity hop bitterness. Light body, moderate-low carbonation, crisp with clean finish. Nice well balanced Helles.
Amber beer that was tremendous. Great aftertaste and smooth fresh well balanced taste.

BOD 2/11/15. Pours a clear medium amber. Normal head volume, outstanding retention and world class lacing.

Subdued nose of biscuit with a hint of caramel. Underneath is a subtle bright floral/herbal hop note.

Light medium body with a smooth texture and hints of creaminess. Above normal carbonation with a nice burst of effervescence in the middle and a prickly rush in the finish. 

The flavor profile is near world class. It is intense, rather complex and fairly well balanced. A bit more malt sweetness to balance the hops would yield a world class flavor rating. It begins with herbal hop flavor over a mild biscuit sweetness. As the middle approaches, light caramel notes emerge. The middle brings a mild bitterness over a slight mineral like note. The finish is a slow fade into biscuit and bitterness over a mineral note that is somewhat dry and crisp.

On tap 4 oz. sampler at Westover Beer Haus in Arlington, VA. 

Clear gold with a thin off-white head and fair lacing. 

Aroma of biscuits, caramel, grain and toast. 

Taste of biscuits, caramel, toast, mild cloves and grassy hops. 

Full/medium body and medium/low carbonization.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Bottled on:  01/23/15.  A clear amber pour with a thick beige head.  Lots of sweet caramel, vanilla cream, freshly baked bread, lightly toasted grains, and just a hint of oranges feature in the aroma.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied.  Lots of caramel and toffee upfront in the taste.  A doughy, bready middle.  Just a bit of citrus finishes things off.  Slightly herbal throughout.  Enjoyable.
Poured hazy golden with a thick white head. Aroma of biscuits, cereal, hops. Slightly sweet, slightly bitter. Good German flavor.

Pours a nice gold yellow with medium white fluffy head. Aroma is sweet fruity, grassy hops hops, grains and biscuit malt. Taste is the same with a good hops bitterness. Plate is a medium crisp body, good carbonation. Finish is sweet with grains and biscuit malt, bready light yeast with a hops bitterness on the end. Leaves a lingering hops bitterness and malt aftertaste. A good and balanced brew.
Bottle. Pours out exactly like the picture shows. Lively carbonation and body, hoppy smell, some fruity notes as well. Easy to drink, maybe a bit too heavy for the spring time, but still, not bad.

On tap at Red Robin, Hershey. 
This was poured into a pilsener glass. 
The appearance was a hazy golden burnt orange color with no head nor lacing. I figured it was a bar pour so Im not too worried. 
The smell had a big malty sweet corn, bready / biscuity goodness to it.
The taste was mainly sweet and bready. Light bready to slight corn aftertaste that ran into a light sweet wet finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was fairly smooth and good. 
Overall, I say this was a pretty good Maibock / Heller, if anything, definitely one to put with food.

Satisfying. Whats nice about this beer is that it has a sweet and toasty malt forward feel, but its also followed by a whimsical floral note toward the finish. The aroma is totally boring, but the taste makes up for it. The finish seems a little punchy with the hops--I would have liked that a little bit smoother. For the style, however, you really cant go wrong giving this one a try.
Decent. Pours clear yellow orange with little head. Aroma is a bit funky malt. Medium body, light skunk finish.
Floral, muscat nose. Flavor is same plus bready, lemon marmalade, orange zest.

12 oz bottle. Pours deep golden with tall, long lasting, fluffy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is of grassy hops, bready malt and hint of alcohol. Body is full and crisp. Taste is of sweet biscuit malt balanced by grassy hops and drying alcohol. Finish is long, dry. Good warming brew.
Pours a deep golden color with a medium sized off white head. Notes of baked sweet breads, earth, green hops. Medium weight mouthfeel.
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2015 Bottle. Pours a golden orange color with white head. Pils malt, herbal hops, cereal, slight earthy aromas. Herbal, earthy, slight resiny, biscuit flavors.

Pours a sharp and clean straw gold with two fingers of white head. Nose is grassy with some sweet bready notes and straw, a touch dextrinous. Bready and dextrinous in the flavor with a spicy/citrusy/floral quality. Bright and crisp with a malty finish and light body. A very very light smokey quality shows as well.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a deep gold color with a white head. Clean, malty aroma with a just-under-medium mouthfeel. Deep malt flavor without being too sweet.
Bottle pour into a snifter. The beer is a pale copper with not much head. The aroma is grainy and grassy. Tastes a little bitter. Somewhat sweet as well. Light body and medium carbonation.

On tap at Arooga's. Pours a very clear, light amber with a nice white creamy head. Excellent peeled lace. Aromas of toasted grains, pilsner malts and light floral hops. Medium-light body, creamy and a nice crisp. Refreshing. Tastes the same as it smells with dried grassy notes and light caramel notes. I shouldn't be surprised that this is as good as it is. This is Troegs we're talking about.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a 12 Oz into a pilsner glass. Pours a light blonde yellow. Lots of frothy white head. Mild boozy aroma. Mouthfeel is great for a hefty lager. Taste is ok but not great. GERMAN flavor from yeast and lagering decent but not great.

Some nearby bodega: Pours light orange with a white head. Aroma is light fruitiness, bazooka joe, and some breadies. Taste has a very mild hoppy tinge. Sweetness is pretty low. Well balanced. Tasty and easy to drank.
Draft at Red Star Exton. Hazy dark straw with off-white head. Bready malt, hops, mild nuts, molasses in the nose. tastes like a maibock with more grainy and hop notes.

Drank from a twelve ounce bottle purchased from Wegmans. Aroma of beer and citrus. Zero initial taste, then bitterness on the center of the tounge, than a lil bit of a bite at the end. Not a big fan.
Draft at Barcade JC with Paul. Pours a clear gilden with thin white lacing. Aroma is clean malt and grass. Mouthfeel is clean and crisp with notes of sweet bready malt, spice and grass.

Im very much in favor of a craft brewing alternative to our bland or cloying mass produced pilseners. So when I found a 12 pack of Cultivator for $12, I grabbed it. Just what I have been looking for, a lighter beer with character and flavor at a reasonable price. Congratulations to Troegs, a fine brewery, for filling a missing niche in the beer spectrum!
Faint smell of caramel malt. Taste is a blend of light caramel and some mild pine hops.
Poured from a bottle at domion ion beer and wine it is a clear gold color with no head. The aroma is pineapple and the taste is rather strong malty with a bitter ginish
Tasting at Dominion Wine and Beer Falls Church, VA. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Aroma of biscuit. Flavors of toast. Medium bitter finish.
Light grain aroma. Clear dark golden color with a large white head. Mild beginning with a light bitter middle and end.
Pours a clear amber with a good sweet aroma. Nice malty flavor, good balanced hoppiness, good beer.

Bottle poured a dark golden color with a thin coating of white head. Aroma has grains, mild malts, flowery hops, and some bread. Mouth feel is medium light with mid range carbonation. Flavor has sweet malts, flowery hops, bready, and a light bitterness into the finish.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a beautiful golden color. The head is about a finger high, and white in shade. The texture is rather frothy and inconsistent, while retention is only average. However, some streaks of lacing are left behind on the glass. Generally, this is a good-looking offering.

S: Theres a lot going on with the aroma. At first, Im picking up various fruity notes (apples, lemon, maybe even some melon) backed with some subtle baked bread. Letting it open up, and some grassy hops will appear. Everything seems nicely balanced, well integrated, and defined. This proves you dont need to be a massive Galaxy-hopped DIPA or bourbon-barrel aged imperial stout with coconut to have a great aroma.

T: Subtle hoppiness hits the palate first - both grassy and a little herbaceous. Malt flavors surge after the hops fade (slightly) with caramel, baked bread, and apple. Id even suggest this beer tastes a bit like apple pie. Its best feature is its balance: this could have easily been too sweet, but the hops helps to give it a ballasting bitterness, while still allowing the defined malt flavors to shine through. Maybe its not complex per se, but I dont care about that.

M: The crisp, dry finish helps to neutralize any excess lingering sweetness on the palate. There is a good amount of body to help give it both substance and a long-lasting finish (in spite of the dryness), but it still goes down disturbingly easy. Carbonation is nearly perfect.

O: Gorgeous, gorgeous beer. I had high expectations for this, and they were met easily. While everything is balanced well, its the former combined with the flavor definition that makes it the winner it is. Hold on, let me drink another to see if Im right about this one...yep, dead-on about this.

Transfer from BA review on 3-3-14-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer pours a golden amber color with tons of big carbonation bubbles seen streaming up through the brew and with a small fizzy white head. The head fades quite fast leaving a light level of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma of the beer is strongest of a big bready smell. With the bready smells are some big aromas of toffee as well as a decent sum of a lighter fruit smell. The fruit aromas are mainly of apricot, peach and plum and with bit of a doughy and grassy smell rounding out the aroma, the smell is overall a nice blend of sweet and malt.

 Taste  The taste begins with a thick doughy and bready flavor with lots of caramel sweetness right from the start. The caramel takes on more and more buttery flavors as the taste advances producing a toffee like taste. Along with the caramel to toffee transition, so too come some hop flavors of a light grassy and moderate earthy flavor growing more intense as the flavor advances. A light graininess and a little bit of grape and pear come to the tongue at the very end of the taste, leaving a nice, lightly hopped, very sweet, and malty flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the thicker and creamier then would have been expected for a brew of 6.9 % abv with a carbonation level that is rather average. The thick and creamy body are fantastic for all the big sweet toffee and doughy flavors of the brew, coating the mouth in all the nice malt and sweet flavors.

 Overall  A rather sweet, but still just enough hopped and balanced Helles Bock. Due to the thicker body and big sweeter and bready flavors, it is a rather slow drinker all while only at 6.9 % abv.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 9/7/14


Aroma: The nose of this one is strong lemon with some doughy/bready malts

Appearance: It pours a murky orange color with a frothy beige head and plenty of lace

Flavor: The flavor falls along the same line, bready malt sweetness with lemon and hop flavor

Palate: The body is light-medium, with a strong carbonation, and a lightly dry, tingly finish

Overall Impression: 
Solid stuff. Thats the only real impression that this beer left on me. Beyond that, I find it really annoying when they have 10 1:00 games and only 2 4:00 games.

On tap @ SL Liquors. Pours a crystal clear deep golden color with a one finger dense off white head. The aroma is of gentle floral hops, light pine, and a heap of bready malt. Tastes of sweet malts, crisp hop bitterness, light caramel, and biscuit, that is sweet & dry on the finish. Light bodied and crisp with mild carbonation.

Bottled 013114 (is that right?). Nose is sweet and citric with sunny malt, overall very bright, with very light swashes of grain and candy sugar. Clear orange body with slow, light carbonation and a dense, sudsy off-white head. Taste of sunny malt with muscat and white grape, super soft light (but not watery) body, lacks lager crispness but has that little snap, that thinness that quickly pulls things into focus. Roughness form the graininess at the back but there are hints at much deeper, not fully explored malt complexity that compensate. Clean, faint spice and floral undertones.  Alcohol pushes around the edges but it held off. Really easy-drinking, a nice little local find.

12 ounce bottle into lager glass, bottled on 2/6/2014. Pours fairly crystal clear deep gold color with a 1 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, toast, biscuit, honey, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance of pale malt, earthy hop, and yeast ester notes; with good strength. Taste of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, toast, biscuit, honey, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness. Light-moderate earthy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, pear, apple, cracker, toast, biscuit, honey, herbal, grass, light pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Very nice balance and robustness of pale malt, earthy hops, and yeast ester flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Very clean flavor profile as well. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth, crisp, and lightly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent Helles bock! All around great balance and robustness of pale malt, earthy hop, and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth, clean, and crisp to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2016 Single bottle from W&M Mansfield. Pours out a slightly hazy medium golden color. Thin lacy white head. Honey-sweet aromas and flavors that are somewhat balanced. Some fruitiness. Clean finish. 2016 Re-rate: Bottle from the mix pack. Must be a much fresher bottle. Major upgrade!

Pours a light gold color with a small white head. Light floral and cookie dough nose. There is a nice round maltiness up front with a little floral bitterness on the back end and a dry, clean finish. Simple and clean, just like it should be.

Pours a clear copper one finger white head. Decent lacing and head hangs around. Lots of malt on the nose. Very clean taste. Dry finish. Well done!


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma is floral, uncooked dough and sweet malt. Taste follows pretty closely but finishes with a sweet apple note. Nice crisp mouthfeel. Tasty.
12oz bottle. Golden color with almost no head. Malty aroma. Malty sweetness is the overwhelming flavor. Decent beer.
This is a decent bock, though the hops dominate more than the sweetness youd expect. Tried at the Federal House with Jess in 2014.
Pours clear copper with nice frothy manilla head. Aroma very cidery. Real nice creamy mouthfeel. Flavor sweet and mellow not as harsh as many blocks. Overall very drinkable.

12oz bottle. Clear apple juice body with small white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, light caramel, earthy. Taste is moderately sweet, bread, light earthy, caramel. Light-medium body, nicely drinkable.

(bottle) Golden complexion with minimal white head. Aroma is of a macro-brew lager; flat mild malt. The flavor is balanced malt with understated hops.  Long finish where hops and floral qualities are better appreciated. Perhaps lower rating because this is not a favored style for me.  This is a decent PA craft brewer.
UPDATED: JUN 9, 2014 Bottle pours light amber, aroma is floral with light malt. Taste is light bodied with a hint of malt and a semi sweet finish.

Mild hop aroma, with a touch of lager. Pours a clear light amber with just a dusting of white head. Slightly sweet flavor, with just a touch of hop bitterness in the finish. Light mouthfeel, easy drinking for a 6.9% ABV beer. Not bad, but I dont think Ill
Bottle from Hunger N Thirst. Pours golden with a white head. Leaves some lacing on the glass. Not a lot on the nose. A bit oily on the tongue. The finish is slightly boozy. Not feeling this one.

2 dollars for a bottle at vintage. Smells fairly sweet. Looks like pale lager with a decent head. Quite strong with personality on the first taste. Yes, alky shows thru. And now I see its 7%, youd know that from the taste. Yes, stronger beer fer sure, has some negative ale attributes. Hops fer sure baby, dull lager hops. Has decent co2 and I think the smell goes somewhat metallic and some tiny hints of lemon is added tot he buds.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottle. Gold. Aroma is floral and bready. The taste adds toast, grains, and sweet brown sugar. The mouthfeel is medium rich. Tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a golden color with a fairly white colored head, on draft at 2 Stones. Aroma of dough and grass. Flavor of dough and grass and toasted notes, some degree of herbal and earthy hops. Mouthfeel was only moderate to full, hard to believe it had that much alcohol. A good shot at the helles bock!

Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have sweet grainy malts, toasted bread, yeast, grass, a light floral hop profile with mild bitterness to the finish. Not one of my Favs.
From a bottle poured a golden color with a small amount of head. Light malty flavor with a quick finish.

12oz bottle. Sweet rich heller bock aroma. Classic sweet flavor, some flowery hops. Clean and fresh, an enjoyable example of the style. A little bit filtered out, underwhelming in the body. Quality ingredients. respectable execution.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear gold with an inch of head and substantial lacing. Hay, straw, citrus notes. Very sweet flavors--honey, sweet malts, caramel--followed by a very subtle hoppy bitterness that doesn?t quite balance with the sweet. A decent spring seasonal.

12 ounce bottle from Wegmans Lake Manassas. Pours a sightly hazy amber color with a thin frothy off-white head. Fair head retention. Aroma of, well, not much. A bit of grainy malt. The taste is grainy malt, caramel, floral hops, a faint bit of butterscotch, apple and tart fruits in the finish. Thin-medium bodied. Maybe a little TOO delicate. Not bad, but definitely not up to their usual standard.

Location/Date:Bottle on 4/11/2014.
Appearance: Pours orange yellow.
Aroma: Aroma of light floral notes.
Taste: Bready, light floral, lightly sweet.
Palate:Medium light body.
Summary: Glad I got to try, more on the maltier side.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark gold body under a small fizzy white head that faded to a thin film. The nose is very clean, some pale slightly sweet crackery malt with a delicate floral hoppiness. The flavor is just as clean, really nice soft bready and the perfect delicate hoppiness that doesnt dominate or distract from the malt. Crisp and bright with soft fizzy carbonation and a lingering light bitterness. Very nice beer.

Aroma of musty malt, metal and light fruit hop. Clear yellow like any lager. Pear like sweetness, wet bitter aftertaste. Body has a crisp start but is pretty soft overall. Like many bocks, its more filling than it seems. A mellow maibock for rainy April.
bottle. clear gold with a small head. white grape juice aroma. floral hop flavors and grape notes. not much in the way of bready or toasty. medium light bodied. a bit of abv zing in the finish.

Pours a clear golden with a bubbly white head. Aroma is of malts, dust, hops, slight metallic, and yeast. Has a nice boozy/oily mouth feel. Flavors is of a bitternes with malts, hops, a little booze, grains and dirt. Leaves a boozy bitter malt/yeast finish. Im not really big on this style but Im liking this one right now.

From a bottle brought back from the brewery. Pours clear gold with a bubbly off white head and lots of lacing. Tastes grassy, like caramel, musky, citrus feel. Light medium body and carbonation. Smells like nice, rich grains, malt, grass, and caramel notes.

Bottle shared by friends. Pours clear golden amber with frothy off-white head. Aroma is cereal and biscuit malts, light toast, grassy notes, faint floral notes, and light pear. Flavor is dry bready malts, smooth hop bitterness, faint grapefruit, and some herbs/grassiness; dry finish with a hint of lingering bitterness. Medium body and carbonation.
Meh. It?s a nicely crafted beer but mostly unremarkable. Not overly aromatic with a touch of citrus. Bready and a touch of spice. Decent hop profile for a thinner beer. The alcohol is well hidden.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Bready and metallic. More hop flavors, though subtle, than expected. Not bad for the style I guess but I cant get too excited about this one. The bottle I tasted had been sitting around for awhile so I might be judging this unfairly.

Really decent bock. I was happily surprised to see that my pathetic Latta Wegmans actually had a beer I was looking for in a timely fashion. Heavily dominated by dough and bread. Nose also has floral hops. Color is light orange, very clear, with some lacing. Mouthfeel is beefy, mildly hoppy. Finish is dry.
On tap at unos in Hamilton this clear pale amber is just right for spring. Fresh nose and a hint of citrus

A light toasted grain aroma with moderate amounts of flowery aroma from the hops. Appearance is gold with a persistent white head. Like the aroma the flavor contains some toasted malt flavors with a flower like taste from the hops. There is also a long lasting spice note on the end with some sweetness. Moderate hop bitterness levels are present. Balance is still towards the malt. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. That lingering spice flavor on the end leads to an unpleasant astringency. An alcohol warming sensation is noticeable. Overall, it's ok. I would like more malt complexity and the malt bitterness balance to be slightly more towards the malt side. That lingering spice flavor also detracts from the drinkability of the beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Amber, clear, good lacing and head. 
Full body, good carbonation, smooth, rich but balanced mouthfeel, very long palate. 
Bitter, a drier bock, as one would expect from the style. 
Hoppy, herbal. 
Not what I expected for a bock but very good all the same. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by Nicola on 3/20. Pours a pale gold with a small head that quickly fades. Aroma is caramel, toasted bread, floral hops, spice. Taste is grain, almost IPA-level bitterness, plums, stone fruit, clove, banana. Great mouthfeel. Not my favorite style, but for what it is its really nice.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle, bottled on January 30, 2014, poured into an English Pint glass. Pours clear golden with medium white head. Aroma is herbal hops, medium body, low carbonation, and thick big bubble lacing. Taste is herbal hops and toasted grain. Not one of my favorite styles.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2016 Draft at Khyber Pass. Clear gold pour that started with a fairly large foamy white head. Honey sweet toasted wheat. Yellow plums. Tangerine peels. Butter. Bamboo. Lemongrass. Bready but not yeasty. Slightly musty. Not really my style but this is notably a fuller Helles Bock than most.
Bottle from Capones. Pours light amber with some head that fades. nose is biscuits, bready notes with mild floral notes. finish is mild spicy hops and clean like a lager. not bad
12oz bottle in a tulip. Pours copper with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel and nutty and cereal malts plus light hops and light dough. Flavor the same. Average texture. Standard for the style.

Pours golden. Bready, floral aroma. Two finger head with nice lacing. Tastes bready, nice roasted malts, on the sweet side. Lightly bitter, floral hops on the palate. Finishes slightly sweet but dry. True to the style.

Bottle. Textbook example of style ... pure golden hue, white head. Rich sugary and malty aroma that for some really odd reason reminds me of living in Las Vegas (!?). True to style all the way ... crisp, richly malty, thick with drinkable sugar ... robust lager. Well done.. (#5472, 3/20/2014)

12oz bottle pours a totally clear orange with some thin, fizzy white head. Nose is grassy, some brie rind, light malt, lightly floral, some chrysanthemum, dried citrus peel. Flavor is heavy on the yeast, a little doughy, some brie rind, some orange, some grass, some honey. Slick, creamy finish.
Some sweet malt, nutty with a strong earthiness, then a bread-like flavor with toast and light hops in the finish. Interesting.

I rather like this style so this one was a disappointment for me. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bright amber color with a large creamy-soapy yellow-white head that left decent lacing. The aroma was sweet and tangy sugar and vague fruits. The flavor was tangy, dryish and somewhat bitter and off with notes of pepper, vague fruit, a bit of bread dough and a boozy presence. Medium length finish. Moderately full bodied. Disappointing.

Pours a perfect amber gold. Clear and without a single bubble to rise to the top after the pour it is like a sheet of glass. Thick, creamy persistent off white head that leaves spots and streaks of lace. Nose is toasty grain. A slight malt richness and a sweetness too. The hops are floral and pretty , bright and lift the nose right to you. Taste is lovely. Smooth, clean, crisp with moderately high carbonation. A bit rich but not too sweet and the hops leave a soft bitter at the end that is sensational. 

Troegs has again made a flawless and classic beer.

Pours gold into a shaker. Bright white head with medium retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Caramel, toast and earthy hop aromas. Sharp and hot with caramel and toast upfront turning to bitter earth in the lasting finish.
Pours a bright gold with a huge, foamy head. Very tangy with a bit of hop bite. Bread, fruit, and pine notes. Pretty good.

Aroma: Cracked Corn, Floral, Mildly Grassy

Appearance: Golden Straw/Mild Amber Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Mild Lacing

Taste: Floral, Corn, Mildly Bready

Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Light to Medium Bodied, mildly Sweet

leaves, grass, hay, citrus, sour lemon,orange, amber, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, slick feel, flat, average carbonation, light bitter, almost a 
artificial sweetness

On tap at Twisted Jimmys. Mild noble hop aroma, beany with some mild pilsner malt sweetness. Also has a light perfumy note. Medium dull golden amber clear with thin white head. Medium body with medium-heavy carbonation. Starts sweet with pilsner malt and neutral fruity character. No bitterness to it and finishes with carbonic tang and sweet notes. Light hop after.

Fresh bottle, drunk 3/9/14Clear light amber body is well-carbonated, with a small white head showing strong retention.Fresh, floral, lightly citric hops are bright and show just a touch of acidity. No alcohol or other notes and a pretty straightforward sweet white bread doughiness. Light perfuminess and more baked bread as it warms.Sweet, but not overly so and very well balanced by the moderate hop spiciness. Light lemon and orange zest bitterness. The malts are soft and rather supple, carbonation is moderate, and slightly loose. Certainly not going to confuse this for a German bock and it almost seems closer to an IPA (though the IBUs are quite low). Still, its a very well-balanced beer that dosent show its weight and goes down easy. The hops are highlighted and done very well. Spicy, lightly citric and full of peppery bite. Probably one of the least interesting beers from Troegs and Im still scoring this in the mid to upper 3s. Troegs just can not make a bad beer.

Served on-tap at the brewery.


A - Pours clear golden yellow with a decent one finger tall white head, quickly dissipating down to a light film, leaving sticky webs of lace on the sides of the glass.


S - Smells of light noble hop bitterness, doughy yeast, lightly toasted caramel malt and a bit of dulled lemon. Rather plain initially but it comes around a bit as it warms up.


T - Starts off with a mix of bready malt, yeast and mild caramel malt sweetness slowly giving way to the noble hop bitterness. Finish is pretty doughy with some light bitterness, lingering long after the finish.


M - Light body with moderate carbonation. Smooth, doughy feel with some mild bitterness at the end of each sip. Booze is hidden quite well.


O - A pretty solid maibock all things considered. A bit more hoppy than a traditional example but that was what they were going for here. I will definitely enjoy a few more of these once it warms up some more.
draft at Coles, Buffalo. medium bodied light brownish pour. bready, toasty, fruity, floral hops. tasty, well done, not terribly exciting but well made
Poured as taster at local shop. Pours a bright gold color with white head. Lots of malt/bread on nose with a touch of spiciness. Taste is crisp and a bit spicy, nice hop notes as well.

12oz bottle from Crossroads Spirits. Pours a a clear golden color with a large pillowy white head. Aroma of light citrus, sweet grains, floral hops, and perfume. Taste is grainy, slightly yeasty, with notes of citrus zest, and floral hops.

12oz bottle from Crossroads. Poured a good looking clear golden bronze with small bubbles rising continously under a foamy white head. Aroma is malt forward with grains, bread crusts, rye bread, floral hops, spiciness and some orange. Medium bodied with average csrbonation and an average duration on the aftertaste. Flavor is some dry citrus rind, bread, dough, biscuit and rye. Solid beer.

A very light beer made for the summer. Since we just got about five inches of snow, this may not be the best time for this brew but it is still pretty tasty. Lots of grain and bread in the aroma. The flavor has a nice bit of the grain balanced with the hops for a light yet very tasty and crisp feel. On tap at Pinocchios in Media.

Pours a clearr gold with a medium white head...soapy lacing. Aroma has a light malty honey/wildflower honey note and some graasy hops. Flavor is sligntly more grassy and bitter than the aroma. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is dry and bitter/grassy. Nice heller bock.

Clear blonde pour with good white head. Sweet and grainy. Somewhat pilsy malty backbone. Noble hop bitterness. Bready and floral and earthy. A little grassy on the finish. Interesting. But dont need another.
This one poured a straw yellow with a white head. Aroma of grass and pale malt. Flavor similar, decent for the style, but pretty boring overall.

12 oz bottle from Dutchs. Pours a clear golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have sweet grainy malts, toasted bread, yeast, grass, a light floral hop profile with mild bitterness to the finish. Not bad, just not something I get very excited about.
Very nice flavor, crisp with malty kick. Kolsh like hop kick to give nice garden spring like bouquet. Good Representation.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Looks old for the style; a transparent brighter orange with eggshell head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells of bread, lager yeast, and light floral hop notes. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. Alright, but forgettable.
Pours a clear gold with a light white head. Smells of pine, caramel, biscuits. Taste is balanced bitter an sweet - biscuit malts and flowery hops, hint of pepper.
This is a nice change of pace beer. Very light, sorta refreshing. If youre looking for an un-offensive, light hearted brew, this is it.

12oz bottle. Totally clear orange color. Thin white head. Leaves decent reaches of lace. Medium to bigger body. Kind of crisp and smooth lighter carbonation. Lightly slick. Bready, grainy flavor. Lightly toasty. A clean lagery bready flavor. A light bit of piney, lightly zesty hop. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, moderate sweet taste. Solid, moderately hoppy hells bock. Doesnt go too outside the box as far as aromatics, hop profile isnt too distracting. Just a solid example of the style. Looking forward to trying the rest in this new series.
Great clarity and nice, clean flavor. Light bodied and very drinkable. Nothing too exceptional but a nice representation of the style.

Bottle. Poured a clear amber color with an average frothy white head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Solid floral hop and toasted aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium balanced bittersweet flavor with the same smooth bittersweet finish of average duration. Much better than my expectations.

Clear orange-amber body, medium sized white head, sparse lacing. Fresh baked bread, lemon, morning toast, grainy cereals, some DMS in the nose. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, lingering mild sweetness.
Pours deep gold, looks great with a medium White head. Aroma is grass, citrus and floral. Taste is sweet with a crisp tartness. Medium bodied with a dry finish.
Bottled from bt-gct. Yellow I guess, was in the bottle. A large amount of cereal/breast grains, some malts and minor hops. OK. Not special.
A similar occurrence, a very good beer for the style, very crisp and refreshing.
Definitely a spring time beer. It looks like a beer should look and tastes like a springtime beer should taste. Wouldnt drink this beer on a regular basis.
Amazing clarity with a crisp mouth feel and nice carbonation. Flavor has too much corn to it, nose too. Floral hops also in the nose. Next to no head. Very mediocre.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2014 A golden color with a 3 finger head. A smooth beer with an aroma of bread and a strong lemon and black cherry flavor. A hint of bitterness. Not good in a bottle-a skunked, urine smell.
Pours straw yellow with aroma of bread, lemongrass, and toasted malt. Bread flavor with toasted malt, and lemon. Very nice.
